prompt:
Is the person who wrote this in the wrong in the following situation?

"""
AITA for telling my friend she’s still single due to having 5 babies by different fathers?
She finished her 5th divorce two years ago, and for these two years she keeps asking me questions that also insult me.

 “How did you get a man at 30 with kids? It’s because you’re so skinny.” 

“Do I have to stop eating like you? Haha haha”

“You has so many dates. Guys only want basic blondes who are girly.”

“Did you only talk about sex with them?!”

For two years I’ve brushed off the insults, and replied: “ You’re in a small town” or “focus on yourself , and someone special will come around”

Finally she asks for the billionth time “How did you get any dates at 30 with kids?!? You don’t even have a real job! Tell me the truth- why can’t I get anyone?”

I replied honestly and said: “ You have five kids with different dads and none of them pay child support. It’s going to be hard for someone to accept that when you openly are looking for a father figure.”

This launched her into an insult fury, and she hung up on me. 

For reference: I’m not skinny but I work out (healthy weight). I eat more than her, honestly, not starving. I’m girly about some things I guess. I have two kids by the same dad and we split custody 50/50. I work in the adult industry, but only need to put in 8-10 hours a week to make a way better than average income. She keeps insulting my work even though she tried to do it, as well. I also have a vanilla job and an MBA. 

I was tired of being hit low quality and untrue insults, so I replied with what I thought was the truth.

Now, all of our mutual friends are saying I have skinny privilege and such. I’m entitled and don’t understand what she’s going through. They said it was messed up to say that and I’m a shitty friend, and I get whatever I want. She’s not going through anything that major. She’s just dating and being a mom like I had to do. 

Now I’m stuck with my mouth shut, and I’m mad at everyone because I’m not privileged or entitled at all- I’ve worked very hard for anything and everything I have.  And side note- the girl keeps talking about her

AITA for saying that? Was there a better thing to say? 
"""

Is the author in the wrong? Answer A for Yes (the author is in the wrong) and B for No (the author is not in the wrong). Answer nothing else.

thinking.text:
Okay, let's try to figure out if the author is in the wrong here. The situation involves a friend with five children from different fathers, all divorced, and she's been making a lot of insults towards the author for two years. The author finally responds by pointing out that having five kids with different dads might be a barrier to finding a partner. The friend then gets upset, and mutual friends are now criticizing the author, saying they have privilege and were wrong to say that.

First, the friend's behavior: she's been making personal, insulting comments for two years. The author tried to brush them off, but eventually, they snapped back. The key issue here is whether the author's response was an appropriate way to handle the insults or if it was an overreaction or insensitive.

The author's response was to call out the friend's situation as the reason for her being single. Now, the friend's situation is complicated. Having multiple children from different fathers and no child support is a legitimate challenge, but the author's comment might come across as judgmental. The mutual friends are saying the author is being privileged, which might be because they're implying the author's own path was easier. The author argues they worked hard and aren't privileged, but the friends' reaction might stem from the perception that the author is blaming the victim.

The question is about whether the author crossed a line. Even if the friend was being rude, responding with a personal truth could be seen as attacking her situation, which might be a sensitive topic. The author's comment, while possibly true, could be hurtful and not the best way to handle the friendship. The author might have a right to feel defensive, but the way they responded might have been counterproductive. It's possible that a better approach would have been to set boundaries without directly attacking the friend's circumstances, or to not engage at all if the insults were too hurtful.

So considering all that, the author's response was a direct confrontation of the friend's situation, which could be seen as unkind or judgmental, even if the friend was insulting. Therefore, the author might be in the wrong. But there's nuance here. The friend was being rude, but the author's response may have been a justified defense. However, in terms of maintaining friendship and not adding to the hurt, the answer might lean towards the author being in the wrong. So answer A.
